Title:
Independent allohexaploidization events preceded speciation
in Avena (Poaceae) based on low-copy nuclear and plastid sequences
Abstract:
ï¬ The objectives of the study were to investigate the
origin of allohexaploids and understand the phylogenetic history in
Avena L. (Poaceae). ï¬ Phylogenetic analyses were based on sequence data
of three nuclear genes and three plastid genes from 116 accessions of
Avena and those from outgroups. ï¬ We identify three ancestral genome
donors for hexaploids in Avena: x contains genome A, xx contains genome
C, and xxx contains genome D. Molecular data indicate that
allohexaploidy arose independently in A. sativa L. and A. nuda L., and
speciation occurred subsequently to polyploidization. We show that the A
and C genomes diverged from a common ancestor ï½7 million years ago and
that the D genome may have originated from xxx through polyploid hybrid
speciation 1 to 2 million years later. ï¬ The results suggest that the
complex history of reticulate evolution is at least partially
responsible for the taxonomic difficulty associated with Avena. The
newly-resolved phylogenetic framework reflects a major step forward in
our understanding of oat biodiversity and has important implications for
the interpretation of oat phylogenomics
